items.title: Energy Secretary Is Resigning After 4 Years Focused on Clean Technologies
items.author: By Matthew L. Wald
items.abstract: Energy Secretary Steven Chu, a winner of the Nobel Prize, will leave office soon, possibly by the end of this month.

items.title: Where Apps Meet Work, Secret Data Is at Risk
items.author: By Quentin Hardy
items.abstract: Employees who put company information online with their smartphones create a tricky problem for I.T. departments: how to protect corporate data without hindering employees’ work.

items.title: Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette
items.author: By Nick Bilton
items.abstract: Think of how long it takes to access your voice mail and listen to one of those long-winded messages. In text messages, you don’t have to declare who you are, or even say hello.

items.title: Controlling the ‘Smart Home’ With Tablets and Smartphones
items.author: By Nick Wingfield
items.abstract: Newer home automation technologies let mobile devices control functions like heating, lighting and home security.

items.title: Street Smarts: From Holland, Bright Ideas for Highways
items.author: By Paul Hockenos
items.abstract: Under a Dutch plan, “smart” roads would include glow-in-the-dark markings, interactive streetlights, battery-charging e-lanes and illuminated foul-weather warnings.

items.title: A Blank Canvas to Create Smart Limbs
items.author: By Claudia Dreifus
items.abstract: Hugh Herr lost both of his legs below the knee in 1982. Today he designs computerized prostheses and artificial body parts as director of the biomechatronics research group at the M.I.T. Media Lab.

items.title: Data Breaches
items.abstract: An executive for a computer security software developer says they are inevitable in today’s world.

items.title: Smart Ticks
items.author: By C. Claiborne Ray
items.abstract: Ticks have inbuilt guidance systems, honed by evolution, for reaching the ideal attachment points to suck blood — in mammals that is often the thin-skinned area behind the ear.

items.title: European Automakers Hope Technology Can Lure Younger Buyers
items.author: By Jack Ewing
items.abstract: Auto industry managers at the Frankfurt auto show will try to focus on shiny new technologies rather than the terrible state of the European car market.

items.title: New Getty Atlas to Preserve Data on Nondigital Photography
items.author: By Randy Kennedy
items.abstract: The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles will collect and publish information about pre-digital photography to aid scholars and preservationists.

items.title: Delphi Says Autonomous Cars Are Coming, but Only in Bits and Pieces
items.author: By Jim Motavalli
items.abstract: The parts supplier, a General Motors spinoff, said fully autonomous cars are “decades in the future,” but predicted more technology in vehicles.

items.title: Border Patrol Seeks to Add Digital Eyes to Its Ranks
items.author: By Julia Preston
items.abstract: The Border Patrol is focusing on concentrating Border Patrol agents, equipped with late-model surveillance tools, in areas of frequent illegal traffic, while using aerial drones to monitor remote, lightly trafficked spots.

items.title: Smarter Electricity in New York
items.author: By The Editorial Board
items.abstract: The state proposal to decentralize the system to smaller stations that use solar or wind power could lead a national revolution.

items.title: Incentives and Technology
items.author: By Paul Krugman
items.abstract: Yes, we have choices.

items.title: European Regulators Seek to Tighten Rules for Airliner Tracking and Safety
items.author: By Nicola Clark
items.abstract: Officials will soon discuss new requirements aimed at ensuring the continuous transmission of location data for all aircraft.

items.title: Ash Borers and a Deluge of Data
items.abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.

items.title: As Technology Makes Bicycles Lighter and Faster, It’s the Cyclists Falling Harder
items.author: By Ian Austen
items.abstract: The strength, lightness and design flexibility offered by carbon fiber have ensured its dominance at the Tour de France.

items.title: Lightweight Lounging on Racecar Technology
items.author: By Dan Rubinstein
items.abstract: Halo is the first chair made with Hypetex, a new colored carbon fiber developed by Formula One engineers.

items.title: Why Is Our Sci-Fi So Glum About A.I.?
items.author: By Jayson Greene
items.abstract: Semi-brainless B-movies about expanding the human brain keep coming.

items.title: Art and Technology Take a Role in Woodworking
items.author: By Kathleen Beckett
items.abstract: A British craftsman uses a broad definition of the tools of his trade.

items.title: Streamlining the Lowly Wallet in a Digital Age
items.author: By Greg Beato
items.abstract: Since 2011, the crowdfunding site Kickstarter has financed thousands of wallet projects, producing ones made of wood, fire hose canvas and even leather.

items.title: Philae Spacecraft Reawakens on a Speeding Comet With Data for Scientists
items.author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
items.abstract: In November, the European Space Agency landed a probe on a speeding comet, but it lost battery power after 60 hours. The spacecraft began transmitting data packets to earth on Saturday.

items.title: Technology to Keep Swimmers Safe
items.author: By Jennifer Jolly
items.abstract: Tech companies are wading into the swim safety market, offering inflatable wristbands and smartphone monitors that can help prevent drowning accidents.

items.title: VW Scandal Shows a Need for More Tech, Not Less
items.author: By Farhad Manjoo
items.abstract: The world is in an uncomfortable lull between the mechanical automobile age and full-fledged computerized intelligence in our cars.

items.title: New Yacht Technology Off to a Rough Start
items.author: By Chris Museler
items.abstract: The technology has proved tricky and dangerous in the ocean racing world, perhaps a signal that it has been pushed out too soon.

items.title: Digital Culture, Meet Analog Fever
items.author: By Rob Walker
items.abstract: The marginalization of the physical has propelled it into the realm of luxury.

items.title: Period of Soaring Emissions May Be Ending, New Data Suggest
items.author: By Justin Gillis and Chris Buckley
items.abstract: Industrial emissions of greenhouse gases rose just slightly last year and seem to be on the decline in 2015, though initiatives in India and China could upset that.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: Airlines Use Wireless Networks to Replace the Seat-Back Catalog
items.author: By Martha C. White
items.abstract: The SkyMall catalog may be gone, but in-flight retailing is alive and well, via the wireless networks that give passengers access to social networks or entertainments.

items.title: Smart Robots Make Strides, but There’s No Need to Flee Just Yet
items.author: By Clyde Haberman
items.abstract: Although fears of a computer-spawned apocalypse, stoked by grim predictions of some scientists, began decades ago, the current state of machines may offer reassurance.

items.title: Museums Embrace Digital Offerings as Visitor Numbers Surge
items.author: By Farah Nayeri
items.abstract: Directors are enlisting technology as a way of making precious works available while keeping them safe.

items.title: S.E.C. Orders Exxon Mobil Shareholder Vote on Climate Data
items.author: By Liam Stack
items.abstract: A resolution, if approved, would force the energy giant to outline for investors how its profitability may be affected by climate change.

items.title: Technology to Make Clean Energy From Coal Is Stumbling in Practice
items.author: By Ian Austen
items.abstract: A large-scale project in Canada to capture carbon from a coal-burning power plant has fallen short of its goal and its costs are soaring.

items.title: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.

items.title: Exxon Mobil Backs FuelCell Effort to Advance Carbon Capture Technology
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: The energy giant is investing in FuelCell Energy’s technology for carbon capture and sequestration, a potential way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

items.title: Smaller Chips May Depend on Vacuum Tube Technology
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: The vacuum tube, a 100-year-old technology replaced by transistors, could make a comeback as a way to shrink computer chips beyond the limits of silicon.

items.title: A Clutter of Documents. What’s a Reporter to Do? Technology Has Two Good Answers.
items.author: By Ian Urbina
items.abstract: Reporter Ian Urbina describes how helpful Voicebase and History Timeline were in reporting his story about the Kemper County Power Plant.

items.title: Can Carbon Capture Technology Prosper Under Trump?
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: Progress has come in fits and starts, but supporters believe a new plant in Texas may provide a clear economic argument for fighting global warming.

items.title: No Data Manipulation in 2015 Climate Study, Researchers Say
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: A British tabloid said American government scientists overstated global temperatures to influence climate talks. Other scientists say that did not happen.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: German Automakers Step Up to Silicon Valley Challenge
items.author: By Jack Ewing and Mark Scott
items.abstract: BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen are striving with increasing urgency to ride the digital wave sweeping the industry, before it rolls over them.

items.title: Trump Leaves Science Jobs Vacant, Troubling Critics
items.author: By Cecilia Kang and Michael D. Shear
items.abstract: Scores of scientists and technology experts have left the White House, and conservatives — and the president — have questioned whether they need to be replaced.

items.title: A Quick Guide to Backing Up Your Critical Data
items.author: By J. D. Biersdorfer and Kelly Couturier
items.abstract: On World Backup Day, here’s a quick guide to safeguarding your digital photos, videos, documents and emails by creating second copies of them.

items.title: To Curb Global Warming, Science Fiction May Become Fact
items.author: By Eduardo Porter
items.abstract: Geoengineering, providing methods to offset climate change by applying scientific fixes rather than changing old habits, may have found its moment.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: Scientists Fear Climate Data Gap as Trump Aims at Satellites
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Even if Congress votes to keep NASA environmental missions, the nation’s climate monitoring faces challenges, researchers say.

items.title: Going Digital to Rescue Food
items.author: By Tina Rosenberg
items.abstract: Programs designed to avoid wasting food are now using algorithms and networks to match food to hungry people.

items.title: Trump, Prioritizing Economy Over Climate, Cites Disputed Premises
items.author: By Mark Landler, Brad Plumer and Linda Qiu
items.abstract: The president’s withdrawal from the Paris accord seemed more about his belief in the potential to save jobs and ease economic burdens than any disbelief in climate science.

items.title: Energy Department Closes Office Working on Climate Change Abroad
items.author: By Brad Plumer
items.abstract: The elimination of the Office of International Climate and Technology is another sign of the Trump administration’s retreat on global warming policy.
keywords: Office of International Climate and Technology

items.title: Smuggling of U.S. Technology Is Outpacing Cold War Levels, Experts Say
items.author: By Ron Nixon
items.abstract: China, Russia, North Korea and Iran are relying on smuggling rings to secure equipment that can be used for weapons, satellites and fighter jets.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Kobe Steel Faces Japan Government Inquiry Over Data Scandal
items.author: By Makiko Inoue
items.abstract: The company said it would cooperate with “relevant authorities” over practices that cast a shadow over the country’s vaunted manufacturing abilities.

items.title: Georgia State, Leading U.S. in Black Graduates, Is Engine of Social Mobility
items.author: By Richard Fausset
items.abstract: Georgia State, once seen as a night school for white businessmen, has reshaped itself amid a moral awakening and a raft of data-driven experimentation.

items.title: California Today: Baby Steps Toward Autonomous Flying
items.author: By Cade Metz and Matt Stevens
items.abstract: Wednesday: Passenger aircraft that can fly on its own, the state fully abolishes cash bail, and an odd avocado toast recipe.

items.title: North Carolina, Warned of Rising Seas, Chose to Favor Development
items.author: By John Schwartz and Richard Fausset
items.abstract: The legislature passed a law in 2012 to ignore evidence of sharp long-term rises in sea level, so the state’s fragile coastline would go on booming.

items.title: For BP’s Chief, Technology and the Environment Matter Most
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: Nearly a decade after the oil rig disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, Bob Dudley talks about his firm’s focus on the future.

items.title: He Promised to Restore Damaged Hearts. Harvard Says His Lab Fabricated Research.
items.author: By Gina Kolata
items.abstract: Findings that would have revolutionized treatment of heart attacks were based on falsified and fabricated data, revealing weaknesses in medical research.

items.title: DealBook Briefing: What a Digital Iron Curtain Could Mean for Tech
items.abstract: A grace period in corporate America’s freeze-out of Huawei might not help the tech company very much.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Drive Smarter
items.author: By Lisa Friedman and Eduardo Garcia
items.abstract: Also this week, climate report cards for Democratic candidates.

items.title: ‘Very Smart People,’ but a Keyless Car’s Downside Killed Them
items.author: By David Jeans
items.abstract: A couple with careers in academia and science died of carbon-monoxide poisoning. A second congressional bill has been introduced to mandate safety features.

items.title: NOAA Data Confirms July Was Hottest Month Ever Recorded
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Data from federal researchers confirmed that July was the hottest month on record, edging out the previous record-holder, July 2016.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Smarter Laundry
items.author: By Kyla Mandel and Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Also this week, news about meat and what it means for climate.

items.title: China Masters Political Propaganda for the Instagram Age
items.author: By Li Yuan
items.abstract: Leveraging celebrities, the know-how of tech companies and images built for social media, the Communist Party can effectively stir patriotism among the youth.

items.title: Rich Counties Get More Help to Escape Climate Risk, New Data Show
items.author: By Christopher Flavelle
items.abstract: FEMA's buyout money goes disproportionately to high-income counties, new research shows. The findings raise concerns about fairness and efficiency.

items.title: Tech’s Environmental Impact and What You Can Do About It
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: There are many eco-conscious steps to take around your tech, says John Schwartz, a climate reporter. Tech can also help us see the scope of climate change.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Be Smart About Holiday Lights
items.author: By Kyla Mandel, Nadja Popovich and Lisa Friedman
items.abstract: Also this week: air pollution in augmented reality, and new climate talks
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: ‘Call of the Wild’ Casts a Digital Star. Is He a Good Dog?
items.author: By Julia Jacobs
items.abstract: Filmmakers created their lead canine using computer generated imagery. But the question remains whether audiences will be on board.

items.title: In Negotiations, Givers Are Smarter Than Takers
items.author: By Adam Grant
items.abstract: Generosity is a sign of intelligence, and givers are the rising tide that lifts all boats.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: A.I. Is Helping Scientists Understand an Ocean’s Worth of Data
items.author: By Tatiana Schlossberg
items.abstract: Machine-learning applications are proving to be especially useful to the scientific community studying the planet’s largest bodies of water.

items.title: Helping the Environment, One Small Sensor at a Time
items.author: By Ellen Rosen
items.abstract: New York City nonprofits are using a cloud-based service from the start-up Temboo that helps monitor storm-water runoff and other environmental factors.

items.title: Pandemic’s Cleaner Air Could Reshape What We Know About the Atmosphere
items.author: By Coral Davenport
items.abstract: Coronavirus shutdowns have cut pollution, and that’s opened the door to a “giant, global environmental experiment” with potentially far-reaching consequences.

items.title: New Data Shows an ‘Extraordinary’ Rise in U.S. Coastal Flooding
items.author: By Christopher Flavelle
items.abstract: Rising seas are bringing water into communities at record rates, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Tuesday.

items.title: The Smart Home Device Every Home Needs
items.author: By Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.abstract: A new spin on an old tool.

items.title: A Step Forward in the Promise of Ultrafast ‘Hyperloops’
items.author: By Eric A. Taub
items.abstract: Two employees of Virgin Hyperloop traveled on a small system the company has built near Las Vegas, the first such manned test.

items.title: He Created the Web. Now He’s Out to Remake the Digital World.
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: Tim Berners-Lee wants to put people in control of their personal data. He has technology and a start-up pursuing that goal. Can he succeed?

items.title: In Coinbase’s Rise, a Reminder: Cryptocurrencies Use Lots of Energy
items.author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
items.abstract: The company’s stock market arrival establishes Bitcoin and other digital currencies in the traditional financial landscape. It also elevates a technology with astonishing environmental costs.

items.title: Newer Planes Are Providing Airlines a Trove of Useful Data
items.author: By Christine Negroni
items.abstract: During the pandemic, older aircraft have been retired, resulting in a fleet that can collect more information about emissions and safety.

items.title: The White House warns that the U.S. lags behind China on developing clean technologies.
items.author: By Katie Rogers
items.abstract: A new report warns that, without a significant investment in research and development, America could become dependent on its competitors.

items.title: A Million Years of Data Confirms: Monsoons Are Likely to Get Worse
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: The annual summer monsoon in South Asia begins this month. A new study points to more destructive storms.

items.title: Born on the Left, Data for Progress Comes of Age in Biden’s Washington
items.author: By Lisa Lerer
items.abstract: A liberal think tank has grown comfortable with mainstream influence. Other activists say that being “normie” means it’s selling out.

items.title: What Technology Could Reduce Heat Deaths? Trees.
items.author: By Catrin Einhorn
items.abstract: At a time when climate change is making heat waves more frequent and more severe, trees are stationary superheroes: They can lower urban temperatures 10 lifesaving degrees, scientists say.

items.title: Tech Can’t Fix It
items.author: By Shira Ovide
items.abstract: Climate change and other big problems won’t be solved by tech alone.

items.title: White House Aims to Reflect the Environment in Economic Data
items.author: By Lydia DePillis
items.abstract: The Biden administration has set out to measure the economic value of ecosystems, offering new statistics to weigh in policy decisions.

items.title: Beyond Silicon Valley, Spending on Technology Is Resilient
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: Despite an uncertain outlook, corporations plan to continue investing in their digital projects — a source of stability for the economy.

items.title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
items.author: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Tim Wallace and Zach Levitt
items.abstract: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.

items.title: What Good Are Wearable Computers if the Data Is Wrong?
items.author: By Brian X. Chen
items.abstract: An Apple Watch or a Garmin can draw incorrect conclusions about your health, but the broad trends may be more valuable than the numbers.

items.title: New Rules for Power Plants Could Give Carbon Capture a Boost. Here’s How.
items.author: By Brad Plumer
items.abstract: The technology has struggled to gain traction, but strict new emissions limits for gas and coal stations could encourage broader adoption.
